Legal_Issue: Did the Visa Officer err in refusing the applicant's self-employed person class permanent residency application?
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, subsection 88(1)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant had full-time employment and lacked sufficient world-class experience
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate error
Legal_Rule: Applicant must meet the definition of a 'self-employed person' under subsection 88(1) requiring relevant experience and ability to make a significant contribution
Grounds_for_Claim: Contested refusal of permanent resident visa application under self-employed category
Outcome_on_Merits: Officerâ€™s decision was reasonable and justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's employment history and evidence of world-class experience
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Refusal of self-employed person class permanent residency application
Legal_Rule_Source: Subsection 88(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Defendant_Response: Officer reasonably concluded applicant did not meet criteria based on evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of employment and experience
Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and grant permanent residency
Legal_Provision: Subsection 88(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency under self-employed category
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet self-employed person criteria
Applicable_Process: Permanent residency application process, judicial review
Governing_Rule: Subsection 88(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
